original_content:
When the people of Earth set up bases on the moon, you can imagine that 3D printing will be a key enabling technology. Of course, you could ship plastic or other filament at great cost. But what if you could print with something you can already find on the moon? Like moon dust. NASA thinks it is possible and has been doing tests on doing just that. Now [Virtual Foundry] wants to let you have a shot at trying it yourself. It doesnt really contain moon dust, but their Basalt Moon Dust Filamet has a similar composition. You can see a video about the material below.
It isnt cheap, but it is probably cheaper than going up there to get some yourself. At least for now. The company is known for making PLA with various metal and ceramic materials. Like their other filaments, you print it more or less like PLA, although you need a large hardened nozzle, and they suggest a prewarmer to heat the filament before going to the hot end.

They recommend printing at 210C and 135% flow rate. The material contains about 60% basalt, and after sintering at a very high temperature, the remaining material is all basalt.
This isnt the first time weve looked at filament that mixes in metal or ceramics. Weve seen copper-laden filament from Virtual Foundry used to make rocket nozzles.
title: NASAの研究：月の塵を使って3Dプリントする可能性
body: 月に基地を設立すると、3Dプリントが重要な技術になるでしょう。NASAは月の土壌を使用してのプリントが可能と考え、Basalt Moon Dust Filamentを提供。材料は60％のバソルトで、高温で焼結後にバソルトのみ残る。
titles: NASAの研究：月の塵を使って3Dプリントする可能性
3Dプリントで宇宙へ：Basalt Moon Dust Filamentの紹介
宇宙探索と3Dプリントの未来
Virtual Foundryの新たな挑戦：Basalt Moon Dust Filament
未来の技術：月の塵を活用した3Dプリント
